<html><body><div><div class="StoryText_storyText__C3hWI StoryText_storyText__C3hWI"><div><p>A Columbia man was back in the Netherlands after being detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.</p><p>In December, a<a href="https://krcgtv.com/news/local/columbia-man-detained-by-ice-to-be-deported-following-order-from-new-mexico-judge" target="_blank"> judge in New Mexico </a>ruled that <a href="https://krcgtv.com/news/local/wife-of-deported-columbia-man-owen-ramsingh-not-emotionally-ready-to-speak-in-public" target="_blank">Owen Ramsingh</a> had to be deported.</p><p>His wife, Diana, said that <a href="https://krcgtv.com/news/local/community-rallies-for-columbia-man-detained-by-ice-over-decades-old-convictions" target="_blank">Owen</a> arrived in the Netherlands on Sunday.</p><p>Diana and their daughter arrived there on Monday.</p><p>“We need to apply for our daughter’s dual citizenship, get Owen a replacement passport since they lost his, and look for housing,” said Diana.</p><p>Ramsingh moved from the Netherlands to the United States when he was five years old in the 1980s, after his mother met and married a member of the United States military.</p><p>ICE officials held Owen Ramsingh on two drug convictions.</p><p>His first conviction in 1997 involved a controlled substance.</p><p>At the time, he was a minor but was tried as an adult.</p><p>The second conviction happened in 2011 when Ramsingh had a marijuana possession charge.</p><p>Federal authorities previously held Ramsingh at a migrant detention facility in El Paso, Texas, after authorities detained him in Chicago in September.</p></div></div></div></body></html>
